ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Excellent, can learn a lot. Useful for research.

This class is an excellent introduction to the kind of resource allocation problems that arise in networks. We discussed very relevant and useful models of various networks and algorithms. The course aims to build an intuition for these kind of problems and does not focus on the mathematical details behind the results, so I find the class accessible although I have not formally taken any probability classes. However, you do need to be comfortable working with expected values and discreet probabilities (I have taken MATH244 and CPSC365 which have some probability related material, and did some self-study on the side at the beginning of the course). We had 5 problem sets and a final project. The problems can be hard but Prof. Tassiulas is very nice and helpful. He is also a very clear lecturer and a great person to get to know. Some of the algorithms discussed in class are actually his result back in the day. I would recommend the course if you have some background in probability and are interested in networks.
It is a good course. But it is better you have the background of stochastic process.
Yes, because it encompasses many useful techniques for analysis, which is really helpful for people from both mathematic and practical view points.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course shows me the beauty of theoretical work, and makes me feel great interest in theory work as well. I want to combine system and theory for my research.
It helps me better understand the queue theory better.
The algorithms and thinking behind are inspiring
